dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the window long lines of planes wait for taxi and take off in the November dusk. Their lights blink impatiently. Rush hour at O'Hare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH EMHOFF (30‘s) reads a magazine and”stretches-- her h reaches for the communal bowl of peariits on the bar as s battles jet lag with diet coke and aspirin. She ‘looks exhausted. Her phone chimes. She answers.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Mmam...Yeah, it was delayed...Sorry I got so panicky...It was good to see you, too. I’m glad it worked out. She purrs this last part. Smiles at the response we never hear. She coughs-- deep and wet.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will...Just a little tired and warm. A GATE ANNOUNCEMENT drowns out the conversation. BETH (CONT’D) I gotta go. She sighs and gathers her stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LI FAI (20) stands at the rail of the multi-decked ferry it approaches the pier in Kowloon. The Hong Kong skyline looms beyond the ferry terminal building. The waters of Victoria :Harbor churn with boat traffic and birds. Touri snap photos and locals gather their belongings. Fai looks worn down from the crossing. A SHIP‘S MATE steadies him at the rail. (All scenes between Chinese Nationals are in local Language).

dialogues.speaker: SHIPS MATE
dialogues.text: (subtitled) Stare at something that’s not moving. We’ll be there in five minutes.  CONTAGION 1/14/10 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fai makes his way through the crowded transportation hub- past kiosks and advertisements. He leans heavily on the escalator railing and makes his way down toward to the me He carries a.small duffel, but struggles against its weig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pai sits on the clean and crowded metro with the duffel i his lap. Behind him some very HIP KIDS are joking and laughing. Fai shoots them a look, but the KIDS just keep talking and giggling. He turns on them.

dialogues.speaker: FAL
dialogues.text: I don't know you, OK? So, don’t pretend I do. The HIP KIDS look at each other, convinced he is a madman then they burst out laughing even louder. Fai stumbles aw from them and looks out the window of the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights passing by on the tunnel interior and a strange fi eyed reflection of the people behind him. FAI CLINGS TO A METAL POLE FOR BALANCE WITH BOTH SWEATY HANDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRINA MODELSKOVA (23, Ukrainian model) stands at the bagg claim trying to get a signal on her phone. She’s groggy f the flight.

dialogues.speaker: IRINA
dialogues.text: Hello...Yes....We just landed. I took something on the plane and I feel miserable...To sleep, yes...I am sorry for what I said. I get anxious and I don’t know what.to say...I just wanted te call and teil you that. The bags begin to tumble down the chute.

dialogues.speaker: IRINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would like to go to New York with you very much...OK? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: IRINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes...2 am going to take a bath and a nap when I get to the hotel.. Bye, darling. : Her bag comes down the chute and she walks toward Customs with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irina is through customs. She sees a DRIVER with her name a sign. SHE HANDS HIM HER BAG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kwun Tong is the most densely populated area in the world Clothes hang drying from the windows. FAI makes his way toward an entrance to one of many overcrowded housing blo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny, well-kept studio apartment. Fai’s sister, BAI tur down the radio and goes to respond to the knock on the do Fai enters and greets his sister warmly.

dialogues.speaker: BAI
dialogues.text: Hello. I was worried about you. Was there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: FAL
dialogues.text: No. There is a new TV system in the . casino. It’s very complicated and so we are all working overtime. Fai sits on a small sofa. She works the acupressure point his wrist for a moment-- studies his face,

dialogues.speaker: FAI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s so bright in here. She rummages around for a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: BAI
dialogues.text: If you go get a chicken at the market, I'll cook dinner tomorrow. There‘s a girl from work who I think you will like. I’11 invite her. .

dialogues.speaker: EXT, COTAL STRIP
dialogues.text: Vegas of the Orient-~- neon and the sprawling architectur excess. Familiar names in lights: The Sands, Wynn, The Venetian, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gaming floor is buzzing-- slots, cards and Asian game Roulette and dice. It could be the floor of the Bellagio, but the clientele is decidedly Asian. Two UNIFORMED MAINTENANCE men skirt the action and head toward a bank of elevators. A walkie-talkie crackles with urgent instructions. A man with a TOOL BELT looks frazzle He responds.

dialogues.speaker: TOOL BELT
dialogues.text: (to walkie-talkie) We are on our way to 1219. We are short-staffed tonight. One guy called in sick and someone else is on vacation. More urging from the walkie-talkie. TOCL BELT hits the elevator button.

dialogues.speaker: TOOL BELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 2311 after 1219. Got it. The other Maintenance Man writes down the room numbers as they step onto an elevator full of GAMBLERS . Tool Belt coughs, rubs his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOMAS EMHOFF (40-ish) hustles through the foyer of the school. Thanksgiving themes predominate with children’s rendering of pilgrims, Indians and turkeys. He enters the school’s administrative offices.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: i'm Thomas Emhoff, I’m here for Clark. Clark Morrow. I'm his stepfather. An ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT walks back toward the school infirmary with Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NURSE LEAR (50’s) emerges from a room with a cot with a forlorn looking CLARK (7). His eyes are a little glazed a he has a cough. He walks toward his stepfather. EMHOFF (CONT‘D) Hey there kiddo. Not feeling too well? -

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Tired.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE LEAR
dialogues.text: He said he was feeling very warm in Miss Tatum’s class, dozed off. I took his temperature again since I called-- a touch over a hundred-

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFP
dialogues.text: It's making its way through the family. First his Mother goes down and now the mighty Clark. Let’s go get you and Mom some soup and beat this thing down before Turkey Day.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE LEAR
dialogues.text: Hope you feel better Clark, OK? Clark pulls the door shut behind him by the doorknob as h leaves. A moment later, Nurse Lear opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUSTAFARIANS and THE PHYSICALLY BLESSED drink and smoke fight off ennui with anything they can get their hands on Irina is dragging a bit-- she drops a BEROCCA into a mart glass. A GOATEED TRUSTAFARIAN sidles up beside her.

dialogues.speaker: GOATEE
dialogues.text: (off the drink) What do you call that, Rina?

dialogues.speaker: IRINA
dialogues.text: The Jet Lagatini. I‘m in three different time zones.

dialogues.speaker: GOATEE
dialogues.text: Yeah, how about something not quite so over the counter? She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in a stall-- Irina straddling him. Irina finishes a rail of blow and hands the sterling silv straw back to Goatee. He hoovers in a line of his own and then licks the straw clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She perks up-- his hands bring her mouth to his. They kis deeply.

dialogues.speaker: GOATEE
dialogues.text: Good to see you, Rina. She giggles and grinds. GOATEE (CONT’D) Are you in love with this one? Rafik? It‘s been months now. She kisses him hard-- sucks on his tongue with all her mi

dialogues.speaker: IRINA
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Yes. We’re soul mates. They both laugh. INT. NICE HOUSE - EDINA, MINNESOTA — NIGHT Clark Morrow climbs out of bed and makes his way down the hall toward the murmur of his parents. He‘’s dragging ass INT, PARENTS’ ROOM - CONTINUQUS Clark enters.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Mom? I don’t feel well. A light comes on. Thomas and Beth are in bed. She isn‘t looking so good either.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: My throat is scratchy and I have a headache.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Me, too, honey. You want some water?

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Mmm...Poor guy. You want to curl up with your mom? mT

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Let me see if we have something for you. She gets out of bed and staggers to the closet. She gets her CARRY-ON bag. Takes out some COUGH DROPS AND TYLENOL LIQUID FLU MEDICINE.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: OK. I'm headed to the guest room-— this is now officially the sick ward. Thomas grabs a pillow and heads off. Clark lies down.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I‘m going to see if I can do my conference call from home and then take you to the doctor. She kisses Clark’s forehead. He's warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fai wakes up in the empty apartment. He coughs a few time then swallows hard. Sleep seems to have done little to restore him. He forces down some. water and puts on his shoes. The mor sun tortures his eyes. He squints against the day. Bai’s pet bird squawks at nothing in particular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fai fingers the GROUND FLOOR button. He leans hard agains the elevator wall. TWO LITTLE GIRLS and an OLD CHINESE WO eye him with concern. He rubs his temples. Coughs again.

dialogues.speaker: PAI
dialogues.text: My sister lives here. The doors open and Fai stumbles out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fai is hallucinating now. The world comes at him in ways only he understands. He shifts away from non-existent sha and curses at the birds in their cages. PASSERS BY wonder if he’s drunk or drugged. Fai uses pedestrians and lamp posts to keep his feet. Finally, he settles down hard on the dirty, damp curb. The sun has become relentlessly bright~- he shields his e against it with a trembling hand. Muttering. Fai looks back over his shoulder-- what he sees scares hi into rising. He moves away from the onslaught of a seizin brain and takes three blind steps backward into the stree A TRUCK wipes Fai off the face of the earth with a sudden mechanical ease. He is pulled half-way down the block in suspension before the driver knows what happened. People gather round as blood pools out from his body. Cro fill the street. Dogs come to check out the carnage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irina at a commercial casting looking rough in a short sk She is sweaty and feverish and irritable with the PA.

dialogues.speaker: IRINA
dialogues.text: How much longer? There are five other girls there, also in short skirts. T sit with their portfolics in their laps. Trina crosses to the water cooler. Takes a drink and coug She is miserable. Squints at the light. She walks outside and lights a cigarette with a lighter she borrows from another BORED MODEL. Dials her phone.

dialogues.speaker: TRINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello...Seamus...I‘ve been here for an hour. I feel like shit...I don’t know-- did something last night and it must have had something in it...Yeah, OK. TI know that. I‘ma million degrees...I‘m getting in a cab and going back to the hotel-- getting a massage. T’11 come back and smile tomorrow all they like. She hangs up and curses in Ukrainian. She goes back and leaves the PORTFOLIO case with the PA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTAGION 1/14/10 a.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth stands in the kitchen somehow confused by the coffee maker. She squints at the morning sun. She drops the coff pot and pours coffee all over for reasons that it would t a microscope to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas enters. . ~

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Beth? What?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I have no muscles in my right arm. He comes closer to her.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Sit down. She almost misses the chair.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Did you take too much of that Theraflu shit? She puts her head down on the table and then begins to SH with seizure. EMHOFF (CONT ‘D} Jesus, Beth. Thomas jumps back.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Clarky? Stay in your room for a couple of minutes, OK? Wait till I come and get you. He grabs the phone and dials 911. Somewhere another phone rings. A silly ringtone takes us to... INT. BAI’S APARTMENT - EVENING Bai is shaken by the news of her brother's death as it is delivered over the phone. She holds onto his duffel bag a it. was his body. The desperate sound of her grief brings people into the hallway. Bai collapses into the arms of NEIGHBORS. One WIPES THE TEARS from her face. Another picks up her CELL PHONE as i was a murder weapon and puts it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves from hug to hug searching for comfort. The bird squawks and kicks feed from the cage onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BAL
dialogues.text: I want to go home. I just want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: INT, EMERGENCY ROOM
dialogues.text: BETH EMHOFF is out of it-- trouble finding words, not mak sense. The doctors and nurses work on her. Thomas looks o anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: ER DOC
dialogues.text: Beth, can you hear me? My name is Dr. Arrant and you are in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Why are there so many people here? ER boc You had a seizure this morning, Beth. Have you ever had something like that before?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: There’s a meeting in the big conference room today-- I can be on the speaker phone.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Beth, what are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ER NURSE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Does she have a history of IT think she’s allergic to seizures? Allergies? Other penicillin. medical problems?

dialogues.speaker: ER DOC
dialogues.text: Did she fall recently? Slip on the ice and hit her head? In the shower?

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Beth? Wo. She said she had a sore throat a few days ago. ER Doc What about drugs? MDMA? ‘Ecstasy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTAGION 1/14/10 ll.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFP
dialogues.text: What? No. Nothing recreational. She‘s only taking over the counter stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (sotto) It’s so bright in here-- And with that she goes into another seizure. The ER TEAM moves to put in an IV and stabilize her head. She foams a the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Beth..,What’s happening? What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: ER DOC
dialogues.text: Can you step outside, Mr. Emhoff? He searches her pupils for something~- nothing there. Dr. Arrant orders Ativan and antibiotics. They put an oxygen mask over her face.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFP
dialogues.text: Beth... The ER Nurse pulls Thomas out of the treatment area. He s down underneath a CDC poster concerning H1N1-- instructin you how to cover your mouth when you sneeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Concierge and a POLISH MAID are at the door.

dialogues.speaker: CONCIERGE
dialogues.text: Hello? It’s the Concierge. He takes out a security key and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter. The sitting room is undisturbed. The TV blare MTV. A bottle of EVIAN is half-empty on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: CONCIERGE
dialogues.text: Anybody here? Mr. Khalifa? The Maid steps into the bedroom. Nothing. The bathroom do is not quite closed and the tap is running.

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: Mr. Kieron? He enters the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRINA’s DEAD BODY. Half-covered by a bathrobe. “Blue and xigid. There are pills scattered around and vomit on the floor by her mouth. He turns off the water and closes the door behind him. The maid looks at him-~ searchingly.

dialogues.speaker: CONCIERGE
dialogues.text: We need to get security up here... He picks up the phone and dials security.

dialogues.speaker: CONCIERGE., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope you understand the need for discretion, Ms. Wolski. And then inte the phone. CONCIERGE (CONT’D) Jordan? Yes, this is Kieron...I’m in 404 and there's a...one of the guests has passed away..-Room is registered to Mr. Rafik Khalifa...dis girlfriend...2 think maybe drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth Emhoff is on a ventilator. She is comatose and flat lining. No sign of life from her brain. Icu boc I’m calling it at 6:42pm. The nurses go about the business of disconnecting her fro the machines. Tape is gently pulled from her-- Iv’s taken out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas and Clark watch a MINNESOTA WILD game on TV.  CONTAGION 1/14/10 13. THOMAS’ POV A DOCTOR and a SOCIAL WORKER IN A BUSINESS SUIT come down hallway. Thomas sees them and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: You let me know what happens on the power play, Clarky. I’m gonna go talk to the doctor. We don‘t have to hear every word to know what’s being. sa Just fragments of conversation punctuated by grim body language. The force of the news collapses Emhoff. He squa in the hallway and holds onto his head. The Social Worker’s voice is soothing.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIAL WORKER
dialogues.text: If you want help with arrangements we can be of assistance. Thomas tries to take in what has happened.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: I just...I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIAL WORKER
dialogues.text: Maybe the boy has a friend he can stay with while you deal with this. Thomas nods.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: His biological father lives in Duluth. The SOCIAL WORKER walks toward CLARK. Thomas turns to the boc. EMHOFF (CONT’D) She got back from a business trip. She was tired-- she always got sick when she got on a plane. I don't understand. ER boc You mentioned that. Hong Kong. We checked the latest from the CDC-- the only things were Measles and HIN1. It wasn’t that.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Then what was it?

dialogues.speaker: ER DOC
dialogues.text: She was very sick. We tried everything we could-- she just didn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: From what?

dialogues.speaker: ER DOC
dialogues.text: We don’t always know. Some people get a disease and live. Some become sicker and die. My best guess is that it was either meningitis or encephalitis and with encephalitis we’re in the dark 90 per cent of the time-- if it was summer I might say a bug bite. West Nile. Herpes can cause encephalitis. We can tell you how, but not always why. Her blood work indicated some sort of massive infection-- that’s how.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. She didn’t have herpes.

dialogues.speaker: ER DOC
dialogues.text: If you want, we can order an autopsy-- but I can’t guarantee it’ll be conclusive. There are also grief counselors who are very helpful with this sort of passing. I find that is where most people get some resolution.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE FOYER
dialogues.text: BUSINESS SUIT sits with Clark watching the game.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESS SUIT
dialogues.text: Hi, Clark. My name is. Miss Gage. You want to go get a milk shake or something?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: I’m not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESS SUIT
dialogues.text: Well, I am. Do you want to come with me while your father talks to the doctor? Come on...  CONTAGION 1/14/10 15. She takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man holds on to a HAND STRAP on the absurdly crowded To subway train. His face is sweaty. He Coughs a couple of times, annoying fellow commuters. He mutters to himself a squints against the flashing lights of a tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly he begins to CONVULSE. He falls to the ground SEIZING violently. Onlookers don’t know what to do-- they scramble to make room for the man. A YOUNG WOMAN calls fo Doctor, an OLDER MAN hits an alarm on the inside of the c A WELL DRESSED business man’ stands with his cell phone a at the seizing man-- still twitching and struggling like the victim of electrocution. He videotapes the man thrash around on the ground. Slowly the man comes to a halt-- he lies there on the flo of the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sunlight splashes off the high-rises. A plane vectors on final approach. The white caps fire in the Gulf of Ade

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAFIK KHALIFA (40's) is propped up in an opulent bed befo picture window. He is weak and exhausted. DR. AL-KURDI an the butler AHRAF tend to him. The Doctor reads the thermometer.

dialogues.speaker: AL-KURDI
dialogues.text: {off the thermometer) It's down. You keep resting and you'll beat’ this thing. Take aspirin for the fever and for the headaches.

dialogues.speaker: RAFIK
dialogues.text: I feel a little more myself today-- just so shocking about Irina. They’re still saying it was drugs?

dialogues.speaker: ABRAF
dialogues.text: Yesterday he couldn’t remember my name he was so delirious.

dialogues.speaker: AL-KURDI
dialogues.text: Tf he gets like that again y to take him to the hospital: I think he’s on the mend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahraf neds and takes away a glass of water and plate of e

dialogues.speaker: RAFIK
dialogues.text: Maybe someone can get me a newspaper and some tea. EXT. NICE HOUSE —- EDINA, MINNESOTA - MORNING A WOMAN runs through a snow flurry at. dawn in her bathro She turns up the driveway to Thomas’ house. She is sobbing and holding her cell phone. She arrives at door. Thomas answers.

dialogues.speaker: RUNNING WOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh my God, Thomas. Something happened with Clark. I went in to wake him up this morning and I couldn’t. He had thrown up and he wasn’t breathing. Thomas starts running toward his neighbor’s house. An AMBULANCE red-shifts toward them.

dialogues.speaker: INT, NOBLE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL
dialogues.text: MRS. TATUM takes attendance-- FIVE DESKS ARE EMPTY this morning.

dialogues.speaker: MRS.. TATUM
dialogues.text: So either we're getting an early start on Thanksgiving vacation or there’s a bug going around-- and that means everyone needs to be extra good about hand washing, right? Remember what we learned during swine flu? The kids nod. She pretends to sneeze into the crook of he arm,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. TATUM (CONT’D) Anyone carpool with Luke or Clark? How about Liza or Steven J.? Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Li Bai sits in the waiting room. An older woman enters pushing a cart with a simple URN on it. Bai is still in shock.

dialogues.speaker: BAL
dialogues.text: (off the urn) Is it heavy? I‘m taking him home.

dialogues.speaker: URN WOMAN
dialogues.text: T am sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BAI
dialogues.text: May I have some tea? I am exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: URN WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Tatum heads down the hall toward the office. She pas a COUGHING kid. She arrives at the office.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TATUM
dialogues.text: I need to speak to Nurse Lear. My class is shrinking.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL ADMINISTRATOR
dialogues.text: Lesley called in sick today-- we're trying to find a sub.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TATUM
dialogues.text: The nurse is sick? MR. GREY, the school principal, enters the office-- ashen

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREY
dialogues.text: {to Tatum) You heard?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TATUM
dialogues.text: What? Lesley is sick?

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREY
dialogues.text: Come in. She follows him into his office. He closes the door. MR. GREY (CONT’D) We got a call from Luke Warfield's mother. Clark Morrow and his mother passed away~-- they’re not sure from what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafik’s butler, Ahraf does his morning prayers. The men a lined up shoulder to shoulder on their mats. Ahraf is sweating, but so are many of the other men, he rocks back his heels and coughs repeatedly. The men on either side of him are distracted by the cough it disrupts the prayer. Unable to stop, Ahraf makes his w toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school is being evacuated in accordance with a plan nobody ever planned on using. The buses aren’t where they are Supposed tc be. There’s chaos in the foyer. MR. GREY wears rubber gloves and stands in the crowd of kids-- he a directive that he reads from.

dialogues.speaker: MR. GREY
dialogues.text: Now, you want to go on the same bus that you took to school-- unless your parents drove you or are picking you up, in which case you need to go outside to the baseball field. Again if you have to cough-— into your elbow and wash your hands for thirty seconds. Sing the happy birthday song and you’1ll know you did it right. Mrs, Tatum locks at the clusterfuck in front of her. A ki with PIGTAILS approaches her,

dialogues.speaker: PIGTAILS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Tatum, will you feel my head? Do I feel warm? She is reluctant to touch the kid.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TATUM
dialogues.text: I don’t think they want us to do that, Becca. INT. EMERGENCY ‘ROOM - FAIRVIEW SOUTHDALE HOSPITAL EMHOFF: sits alone in an ISOLATION ROOM-- despondent over loss of his wife and step-son. A mask of grief and shock across his face. A sign on the door says “RESPIRATORY ISOLATION.” A FACE in an N-95 mask appears in the door. A knock on the window brings Emhoff back. He pauses for a moment and then remembers-- he pulls a surgical mask over own face. THE MEDICAL TEAM enters, all wearing protective gear. The regard him as though he is radioactive. They present him with a cup of pills. They take blood, et

dialogues.speaker: ER DOC
dialogues.text: Are there any open chemicals in your house, Mr. Emhoff? Anything in the basement or garage that your son or wife may have come in contact with? He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Why them and not me? I’m not sick.

dialogues.speaker: ER NURSE
dialogues.text: Your temperature is a little high, Mr. Emhoff. Is that normal for you?

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: I don’t know...I have a daughter-- she's coming home from a band trip today. Can someone give me my cell phone? I want to call her mother. A NURSE hands him his phone in a plastic bag. Every ‘item suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: ER DOC
dialogues.text: There are a number of children who are sick at your son’s school, Mr. .Emhoff. The Health Department has asked that we keep you here in isolation for now.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: I need to make arrangements-- the funeral. Funerals.

dialogues.speaker: ER BOC
dialogues.text: The Medical Examiner is going to do an autopsy on your wife and We need to do that te under what is making people sick- need you to call the funerai home and have them release the bodies. I’m sorry. I know this is an incredibly difficult time for you. Can you do that fer us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emheff nods. _He gets the phone out of the plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: I don’t know the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ME and the ASSISTANT ME perform an autopsy on Beth in drab green room. A microphone hangs over the metal table record their findings. On the next table lies CLARK‘’s corpse as well waiting fo autopsy.

dialogues.speaker: MINNESOTA ME
dialogues.text: The deceased is a female, thirty- two years of age. Case was referred to the Medical Examiner’s office 36 hours after time of death on suspicion of meningitis. They begin to open her skull with a surgical saw. They lo into Beth Emhoff’s brain and are aghast.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT ME
dialogues.text: What the heil is that? The ME is dumbstruck. ASSISTANT ME (CONT‘D) You want me to take a sample? The ME looks at the blood and tissue that has been spraye both of them by the saw.

dialogues.speaker: MINNESOTA ME
dialogues.text: IT want you to move away from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Assistant does-- frightened.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT ME
dialogues.text: Should I call someone?

dialogues.speaker: MINNESOTA ME
dialogues.text: Call everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bai sits holding a bag with her brother’s urn inside of i her lap. She does not look well. She swallows hard as the bus pulls into the station. The PASSENGERS gather up their packages and produce and l up for the door. Bai seems disoriented. She does not get up. The passenger next to her is CONFUSED and wants to ge out.

dialogues.speaker: CONFUSED
dialogues.text: (subtitled) Are you getting off? This is Chong’an.

dialogues.speaker: BAI
dialogues.text: (subtitled) . I’m not dressed for the beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONFUSED is baffled by her response and pushes by her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bai is the last off the: bus. She almost falls down. the steps. She too is coughing now.

dialogues.speaker: PULLING UP AND AWAY FROM BAI
dialogues.text: She walks unevenly through the crowded bus station. Peopl cross her path oblivious to the threat she poses. She nea drops her bundle and a YOUNG MAN stops to help her. He takes her bag and she leans on him. They walk toward t exit together. Vanishing into the throng.

dialogues.speaker: LAUGHING VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How do we know you’re not gonna put us all in the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT.. CONDO - CHICAGO’S GOLD COAST - AFTERNOON A large dining room with a stunning view of Lake Michigan November gray and white capped. A party of ten watches DR ELLIS CHEEVER (40's) carve a Turkey as the Detroit Lions the Washington Redskins on a TV in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: According to our records you're more likely to slip in the shower, or get in a car wreck than contract E. coli from Turkey. Cheever gets a kiss from SUZANNE AUBREY (30's)-- the laug voice.

dialogues.speaker: AUBREY
dialogues.text: Elizabeth made the stuffing-- I don‘t think it can hurt anyone, can it, baby? Or, the sweet potatoes. They have little marshmallows for airbags. Plates and platters are passed around the table. ELIZABET NYGAARD fills her plate with salad. Her THREE-YEAR OLD DAUGHTER MISTY tugs at her leg.

dialogues.speaker: MISTY
dialogues.text: T want marshmallows.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Stuffing for Misty, but no bird for me. I’m off the animals. Good thing we didn’t go to Dallas. No animal survives. My Dad makes this Turducken thing... Her husband-- DANIEL NYGAARD-- chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It’s a chicken inside a duck inside a turkey. Not a thing that happens in nature.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHEEVER
dialogues.text: His cell phone chirps-- and he puts down the carving knif and answers.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL CHEEVER
dialogues.text: He fries it in an oi] drum in I'm sorry I gotta take this the driveway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel continues on about the carnivores of Texas as Chee makes his way to the kitchen. Misty follows him.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: {on phone) This is Dr. Cheever...OK...Uh-huh. Outside of Minneapolis...I’m_ heading back to Atlanta inthe morning. I don’t know who’s around off the top of my head, but I’m sure we can find somebody's holiday to ruin. Alright, you enjoy your dinner...I took the Redskins and gave the points. Cheever ends that call and scrolls through his phone. Hit send. As he waits for the phone to ring he jots down some notes on a scrap of paper in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: THE PAPER
dialogues.text: “2 DEAD, 16 reported...Bloomington, Minnesota...” CHEEVER (CONT’D) {on phone) Hey, it's Cheever at about 5-ish on Thanksgiving...I know this kinda sucks, but we have something in Minnesota. I‘m in Chicago, but heading back first thing. If you can meet tomorrow at the office around noon. Bring warm clothes. Cheever puts the phone away. Takes a small bottle ‘of PUR out of his pocket and douses his hands. He heads back in join the others and resume his dinner. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN KRUMWIEDE (30‘s) sits in the Cafeteria with LORRAINE VASQUEZ (40's). They are hunched over his laptop-- plaste with a collection of stickers speaking to Krumwiede’s fascination with conspiracies.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: I showed it to a doctor. He says it doesn't look like epilepsy.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER SCREEN
dialogues.text: A YouTube video of the Japanese man dying on the Marunouc Line.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And it wasn’t some sort of-Falun Gong sarin-attack. Only one person got sick.

dialogues.speaker: VASQUEZ
dialogues.text: Nobody helps him. Is he OK?

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: Read the posts. Some people say it was staged, an art project, some say that he died and they wouldn’t do an autopsy-- covered it up.

dialogues.speaker: VASQUEZ
dialogues.text: Covered what up? Krumwiede clicks on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: Not sure. Maybe Minamata disease-- makes you mad as a hatter. It’s in the fish. There have been outbreaks in the past, but the fishing industry suppresses it. Industrial disease. You know how many people read your paper over a plate of sushi everyday?

dialogues.speaker: VASQUEZ
dialogues.text: It‘s just one man and we don‘t even know what happened.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: Just one man on video tape. We doen't know how many others-~ fish is being shipped all over the world. Send me to Tokyo-- come on Lorraine.

dialogues.speaker: VASQUEZ
dialogues.text: Hobart does our health stuff, Alan, you know that. We have almost no freelance budget anymore. And after swine flu ended up being a punch-line, I think he’1l want to wait.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: You wait a few days and this will be tweeted and MySpaced all over the planet.

dialogues.speaker: VASQUEZ
dialogues.text: I’1l ask Hobart.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: You're gonna give him my story, aren’t you Lorraine?

dialogues.speaker: VASQUEZ
dialogues.text: (offended) What? Alan—

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: I taped this meeting. This story runs in the Chronicle I will sue your ass. He shows her a tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: VASQUEZ
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Alan. Don’t call me anymore. She walks away.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: Print media is dying, Lorraine. I'll save you a seat on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emhoff sits in his bed in an isolation room. A NURSE in serious protective gear draws his blood. She places the vials directly in a COOLER and moves from his bedside to sealed vestibule. Another person stands in the air-lock vestibule waiting-- it’s hard to make out much about the person from the amou of protective gear they are wearing. But, they hold a pie of PUMPKIN PIE. COOLER and PUMPKIN PIE share the vestibule for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: COOLER
dialogues.text: Wait until I’m out before you go in, OK? PUMPKIN PIE nods and watches as Cooler leaves the isolati room. She enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emhoff fights through the fear and loss to put on a brave front for his daughter JORY (15).

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Welcome to quarantine. Be careful. They might not let you leave.

dialogues.speaker: JORY
dialogues.text: They told me it's isolation not quarantine, Dad. Quarantine is when they lock up everyone whether they're sick or not. Isolation is just when they lock up the sick people.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: From my perspective there’s not much difference.

dialogues.speaker: JORY
dialogues.text: God, Dad-- what happened? Emhoff shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: They were really sick, Jory. There was nothing anyone could do. She tries to understand.

dialogues.speaker: JORY
dialogues.text: Mom sends her condolences. This is from her. She hands him the pie.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: After I eat it they'll probably need to shoot the plate and fork into space.. They don’t even want me peeing in the plumbing.

dialogues.speaker: JORY
dialogues.text: It’s on the news. They say twenty- six people have it now, but like a thousand people have come to the emergency room. But, you're fine, right?

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, I‘m fine. Don’t worry.

dialogues.speaker: JORY
dialogues.text: But, you were with them.  CONTAGION 1/14/10 27.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFP
dialogues.text: Some people are immune. They either don’t get it-- or if they do get it they don’t die from it. Somehow their bodies figure it out. JORY Te Am I immune? ‘

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: I don’t know-- I’ve asked them to try and find out, but they don't seem to know very much yet.

dialogues.speaker: JORY
dialogues.text: Do they know what it was?

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: They sent people over to the house to check for chemicals, food, rodents. Nothing there. The house is fine.

dialogues.speaker: JORY
dialogues.text: So, when do you get to leave?

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. They want me to wait a few. days after my temperature is back to normal-- make sure I can't get anyone sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits on the corner of his bed.

dialogues.speaker: JORY
dialogues.text: You've never been normal. He smiles underneath the mask.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, well normal seems pretty far away right now, but we'll get there. She lies down across the end of his bed-- drapes herself across his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. ERIN MEARS (30's and bright eyed) pulls her Toyota ne to an Audi in the parking lot. She gets a hanging bag fro the trunk and heads toward the elevator.  CONTAGION 1/14/10 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mears sits with Cheever in the mestly empty building read a file. . CHEEVER . We have outbreaks all the time up there--- usually some bug in a daycare center, or a chémical someone has been working with in a basement. Ne ventilation when the weather gets cold, or food that spoils at the county fair. The Health Department contact-~ what's their name? Swanson? Oshman? Mears flips some pages.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Swanson. Oshman is an ER doc.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: They have five deaths and thirty-~ two cases-- there’s a cluster in an elementary school.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: (off the file) But, nothing confirmed. I mean, it’s all just encephalitis. Cheever shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: You get Christmas and New Year’s off for this. Call me when you get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People file into the building on a dreary Late November d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. LEONORA ORANTES (30s, European) notes something on he computer.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: The Marunouchi Line video-~ she watches the man die for t millionth time on the internet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There‘s a knock on the door. It’s her boss-- DAMIAN LEOPO (50's).

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Meeting’s starting. Drug resistant TB forum.

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: Yeah...In a minute. You've seen this?

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: Video. YouTube.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Of what? Leopold moves around the desk to watch. LEOPOLD (CONT’D) Who posted it?

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: Journalist in San Francisco-- claims the government is concealing cause of death.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Looks like epilepsy. Come on, we have people waiting. She gets up and heads to the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OLD CHINESE WOMAN enters the elevator with a package. She does not look well.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUTTON FOR THE 4TH FLOOR
dialogues.text: Smudged and smeared with repeated pressing. She presses i

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hold the elevator! She presses the DOOR OPEN button as well. A MIDDLE AGED M gets on as well.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR OPEN MAN
dialogues.text: How are they?

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: No better. The younger one has fever.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR OPEN MAN
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: (off the package) Vinegar helps. I got the last bottle, . Half the people on the floor have it. The elevator arrives at the 4th floor. She shuffles off. HOLDS THE DOOR OPEN BUTTON for her. Then rubs his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mears sees a man holding a sign with her name on it. She approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Erin Mears, CDC.

dialogues.speaker: SWANSON
dialogues.text: Dave Swanson from the Department of Bealth. Flight OK?

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: SWANSON
dialogues.text: You going to be warm enough? We’re looking at around zero with the wind chill.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: This is the heaviest coat I have. They head off.

dialogues.speaker: SWANSON
dialogues.text: Don’t want you to catch a cold. He

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mears, Swanson and other OFFICIALS from different departm sit at tables taking notes. On the wall is a schematic on brown butcher paper of all cases.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Any cases involving health care workers who treated Emhoff or the boy? An FRESELY SCRUBBED BUREAUCRAT (30's) gives the update.

dialogues.speaker: FRESHLY SCRUBBED
dialogues.text: We have 47 cases and 8 deaths as far as we can tell-- but nothing's confirmed. Because we don’t know what we're confirming yet. We have the health care workers in iso.

dialogues.speaker: SWANSON
dialogues.text: A grief counselor who had contact with the boy has symptoms-- so does the ER nurse. A DIRE LOOKING ASIAN MAN chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: DIRE
dialogues.text: It’s a weekend-- these numbers might be low. People just stay at home sick for a couple of days and see if they get better.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: So at this point I think we have to believe this is respiratory-- maybe fomite, too.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: What's that? Fomite.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Transmission from surfaces. The school kids touching water fountains, door knobs and what have you. It means it lives outside the body for a period of time.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Is that something we want to release to the press?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. DIANE NORDQUIST (40-ish) perks up at this- Assistant Chief of Staff for the Governor.

dialogues.speaker: NORDQUIST
dialogues.text: I think we're going to need to walk the Governor through this kefore we freak everybody out. Is there a big risk in waiting til Monday, Dr. Mears? I mean, we can’t even tell people what they should be afraid of right now-- that doesn’t play well. We tried that with swine flu and all we did was get healthy people scared to death. It‘s the biggest shopping weekend of the year.

dialogues.speaker: DIRE
dialogues.text: I think we need to consider closing the schools.

dialogues.speaker: NORPQUIST
dialogues.text: And who stays home with the kids? People who work at stores, government workers-- people who work at hospitals. When will we know what this is? What causes it? What cures it?

dialogues.speaker: SWANSON
dialogues.text: We've sent samples to CDC...two other labs as well.

dialogues.speaker: NORDQUIST
dialogues.text: {to Mears) How long? MEARS. In 72 hours we’ll know what it is-- if we’re lucky.

dialogues.speaker: NORDQUIST
dialogues.text: Clearly, we’re not lucky.
She's the ORANTES takes the train home past postcard-perfect Lake Geneva. Her phone comes to life.

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: Dr. Orantes...Yes?

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We received a cali from a Dr. Tanaka in Tokyo. They’re sending a sample for analysis.. They have a number of people sick and can’t identify the pathogen.

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Three dead. Seven sick.

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: The man from the Marunouchi Line video? The man with the seizure?

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, his wife and boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cargo plane taxis across the tarmac. Thanksgiving weeke Commercial flights are lined up nose to tail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boxes from all over the world are unloaded roughly by the graveyard shift.

dialogues.speaker: A BOX
dialogues.text: “DANGEROUS BIOLOGICAL MATERIAL. KEEP REFRIGERATED.” It is addressed to the CDC. The NIGHT MANAGER considers the box reads the waybill.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT MANAGER
dialogues.text: (off the waybill into a Nextel phone) We got an urgent for CDC in Druid Hills.

dialogues.speaker: NEXTEL VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We've got all sorts of urgent. The last truck went out twenty minutes ago. He puts the box in the next day’s pile.

dialogues.speaker: WIGHT MANAGER
dialogues.text: Monday it is then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAMELA NEAL walks with her FOUR YEAR OLD BOY past the GIA KELP FOREST toward a bathroom. She looks overwhelmed by t crowds and the pain in her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy is melting down in a big way.7-She holds her phon like a divining rod looking for a signal.

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA NEAL
dialogues.text: tT don’t feel that well, Tiger. Whatever Dad brought home he gave to all of us. Nobody is answering. PAMELA NEAL (CONT’D) Honey, can you just sit here with me a minute. My legs feel really strange... The boy sits down and she holds him close. PAMELA NEAL (CONT’D) (leaves a message) Josh, where are you? I’m at the Shedd and I just-feel awful. Maybe you’re asleep. JI don‘t know that I can drive home...I’m gonna try your uh...uh... She seems to have forgotten the word. She drops the phone and her son picks it up. She walks awkwardly toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (prelap) She flew back Hong Kong, Chicago, Minneapolis. She had a five hour layover at O'Hare. INT. EMHOFF’S HOSPITAL ROOM - DAY EMHOFF is still in isolation. Mears interviews him.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: She felt pretty bad when she got home, but it just seemed like jet lag and then it kinda turned into a sore throat.  CONTAGION 1/14/10 35.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS.
dialogues.text: Did her work involve contact with livestock in any way? We know she was in Hong Kong. On business?

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF _
dialogues.text: A few days for a team-building exercise. She traveled a lot for work.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: She mention seeing anyone who was i11? Anyone on a plane? She maybe eat anything off the street that she mentioned? I know this is a hard time to answer questions.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: She was kind of a food snob-~ don‘t think she would do the street thing. I already gave the Health Department her itinerary and the credit card receipts. Maybe she got it from Clark. There’s like ten sick kids at that school. And I went there too, to pick him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mears considers all the possibilities. MEARS. She went through customs at 11:15am and was on a 6pm flight ‘to Minneapolis. Any idea what she did in Chicago during that layover?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. This is news to Emhoff.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Why? Is there anyone sick in Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mears studies him

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She said she missed her plane. MEARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she?

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: Before we. got married, my wife had a relationship with a man there. Josh Neal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. EMHOFF (CONT’D) Is Josh Neal sick-- did we get this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from. him?

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: I can't- we’‘re investigating all the- Emhoff's anger rises at the prospect of someone to blame.

dialogues.speaker: EMHOFF
dialogues.text: I think I have a right to know. Look at where IT am. I'd just like to understand some of this. INT. NEAL HOUSE ~ EVANSTON, Ii - SIMULTANECUSLY Paramedics are putting JOSH NEAL into an ambulance. Pamel looks on. Yhe Paramedic gets right in his face.

dialogues.speaker: PARAMEDIC PAMELA NEAL
dialogues.text: Mr. Neal? I want you to stay He’s breathing right? I with me here. Can you hear couldn’t wake him. We got me? home and I couldn't wake him. We both woke up sick this morning. He had a sore throat and his head hurt from the light. The PARAMEDIC puts his flashlight in her eyes. Checks her pupils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emhoff watches Mears leave through the air lock-- only th pen she was using to take notes remains on the side table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krumwiede paces while he’s jacked up on coffee. A JAPANES WOMAN speaks on the SKYPE HEADSET on his laptop. Krumwied coaches her on what to say.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: Ask if they've admitted anyone else in status epilepticus. Has anyone else died?
She translates into the phone. Krumwiede waits on a response. Krumwiede

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE WOMAN
dialogues.text: They want to know who you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looks through his. notes.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: Tell them I’m from the World Health Organization.

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE WOMAN
dialogues.text: Alan, I don't think you should-

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: Why are they keeping secrets? Tell them I work in infectious diseases and saw the video on the internet. She translates reluctantly. Krumwiede is keyed up. She takes Krumwiede

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE WOMAN
dialogues.text: They're. transferring me... off the headset and hands it to Krumwiede.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: Hello...Dr. Alan Krumwiede here...

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE ACCENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes...We spoke to a Dr. Orantes in Geneva yesterday. Five are dead—— thirty five cases. makes notes.

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE ACCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you heard anything more about the London cases? I hear they have two clusters.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: (lying) Yes, we know about the London outbreak. .

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE ACCENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Three of our sick work here at the hospital. Massive swelling in the brain. I've seen nothing like it. Krumwiede hangs up. Dazed.

dialogues.speaker: JAPANESE WOMAN
dialogues.text: What did he say? Is it the fish? Should I call my parents and tell them not to eat the fish? Krumwiede gets out a bottle of Purell.

dialogues.speaker: KRUMWIEDE
dialogues.text: (rattled) Uh...1 think you should definitely call your parents,

dialogues.speaker: INT, HOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Mears makes a flow chart of the disease on the wall. It i spreading...More cases now. Behind her on TV a news repor updates the latest information from in front of the hospi

dialogues.speaker: TV. NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: (on TV) Beyond the Edina Executive and her son, five more Minnesotans have now succumbed to what. is believed to be a deadly encephalitis outbreak over the holiday weekend. Officials at the health department are urging people to come to the emergency room if they have any of the following symptoms...fever, sore throat, sever headaches, fatigue or seizures. She kicks it back to the ANCHOR MAN.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR MAN
dialogues.text: Fever and headache and sore throat. It’s not our friend the swine flu coming back around?

dialogues.speaker: TV NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: The official I spoke to did mention that many of the symptoms might appear to be flu-like.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR MAN
dialogues.text: Well, we'll want to keep a close eye on that story for any updates. Next on sports. The Vikings prepare for Monday night's showdown against the Giants. The phone rings-

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Mears.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So, the affair in Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Joshua Neal. INT. CHEEVER’S APARTMENT, ATLANTA - NIGHT Cheever is on the phone in his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: He was DOA at a hospital in Chicago. His wife and kid were also admitted. I’m asking for samples. INT. MEARS’ HOTEL ROOM - INTERCUT Mears is already taping more paper to the wall. The flow chart grows.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: So she either had it in Chicago, or she caught it in Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: We need to check the passengers on the plane from LAX to O’Hare and from Hong Kong to LA. We’re getting the manifests-- it’s just hard on a Sunday. Everyone's travelling because of the holiday.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: If you were going to do a biological weapon-- nothing like a few million family dinners to get it going. People travelling. Shopping. Saying hello and good~ bye. I’m sure it's crossed someone’s mind,

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: It’s crossed a lot of minds. Other agencies aré all over this now.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: (off the weather report) It’s like ten degrees here.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: (joking) Ebola usually happens in warm places-- you rather be on that? INT. HOUSING BLOCK - HONG KONG - DAY". A man in a robe RUNS down the hall. He knocks on the door an apartment urgently.

dialogues.speaker: RUNNING MAN
dialogues.text: {shouting at door) Look out the window...Look. He runs to another door and a third in the hallway opens. COUGHING man emerges.

dialogues.speaker: COUGHING MAN
dialogues.text: What is it? What's happening. More doors are opening now and the inhabitants are floodi toward the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: RUNNING MAN
dialogues.text: They're outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A number of military style trucks are parking and a small army of MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS in masks move quickly on th building. There are ARMED PERSONNEL wearing masks as well. They ent the building and seal off the exits. A MAN WITH A MEGAPHO speaks.

dialogues.speaker: MEGAPHONE
dialogues.text: Residents of Chrysanthemum Gardens. Please stay in your apartments. We will be coming door to door with medical treatment. Please stay inside. This is for your own safety and the safety of your neighbors. But, some of the panic stricken residents are making a ru for it. The RUNNING MAN jumps out a second floor window a is heading round the corner when he is apprehended by a SOLDIER. But, other RESIDENTS escape scattering into the crowds. Running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two nurses take the temperatures of those who do not run- THE OLD WOMAN AND HER CHILDREN are in line. They call out the RESULTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are put in the truck. Next, the man from the elevato

dialogues.speaker: RESULTS 2
dialogues.text: Normal. And the man is allowed to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. ALLY HEXTALL (40's) and her colleague-- DR. DAVID EISENBERG (30's, Israeli) put on protective BLUE SUITS wi 95 masks with Plexiglass face shields. They make their wa through the air-locks and chambers.

dialogues.speaker: EISENBERG
dialogues.text: You have a good Thanksgiving?

dialogues.speaker: HEXTALL
dialogues.text: I worked.

dialogues.speaker: EISENBERG
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Really? You?

dialogues.speaker: HEXTALL
dialogues.text: Salmonella thing in Texas-- pretty limited. They move past centrifuges and incubators-- mechanical bo and microscopes. They arrive at an air-locked compartment in the wall. Eisenberg opens it and retrieves THE PARCEL. He puts it o table and begins to open it. Careful not to lance his sui with a BOX CUTTER. HEXTALL (CONT’D) What do we have? Eisenberg delicately opens the blood sample from its containment. He places it in a centrifuge.

dialogues.speaker: EISENBERG
dialogues.text: Young woman in Minnesota-- goes into a coma after seizure. Dies a few hours later. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: EISENBERG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Recently traveled to China. Son also died. As of this morning, 87 cases and fifteen dead. Hextall opens the tissue sample of brain. She places it o tray. Speckles of blood on her rubber. gloves.

dialogues.speaker: EISENBERG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is it anywhere else yet?

dialogues.speaker: HEXTALL
dialogues.text: (off the brain) Yeah, it’s on my gloves.

dialogues.speaker: INT, WHO
dialogues.text: The daily briefing. Ten people sit around a table watchin slides of the evacuation from the CHRYSANTHEMUM GARDENS housing block in Hong Kong. j

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: What we are hearing from Beijing is that the outbreak is contained to Chrysanthemum complex in Hong Kong. | Two deaths and ten suspected cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Asian Doctor is dubious.

dialogues.speaker: DUBIOUS
dialogues.text: Nothing in Hong Kong is contained.

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: How may people live in Chrysanthemum?

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Six thousand. It’s central Kowloon.

dialogues.speaker: DUBIOUS
dialogues.text: Hospital admissions?

dialogues.speaker: LECPOLD
dialogues.text: They are not disclosing yet.

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: Is there any vinegar left in the stores?

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD
dialogues.text: Vinegar?  CONTAGION 4/14/10 43.

dialogues.speaker: DUBIOUS
dialogues.text: Traditional remedy. If the vinegar is gone-- we're way behind the curve. LEOPOLD . The Chinese are sending sariples. Should be here in 24 hours. An INDIAN DOCTOR starts handing out a report.

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN DOC
dialogues.text: OK, we are seeing Cholera in Bangladesh in large numbers following the flooding. The slides are now of Bangladesh. The world never runs ou of the sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheever heads toward the entry. “ROGER the JANITOR (50's, African American) takes a hit off ‘his INHALER as he move some trash bins.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Morning, Dr. Cheever.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: You kicked ass’ in the pool this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Go Falcons! Cheever is clocked by a MAN ON A BENCH who is talking on cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: BENCH MAN
dialogues.text: Dr. Cheever? Cheever stops.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: Can I help you.

dialogues.speaker: BENCH MAN
dialogues.text: Dennis French, Department of Homeland Security. Have a moment? Cheever shrugs. French finishes up his call.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: {to phone) t found him-- tell the unit on the way to his house to come in. Cheever is alarmed by this.
Cheever, French and CDC ASST. DIRECTOR LYLE HAGGERTY who in his COAST GUARD UNIFORM. French has photos of the enforced quarantine in Kowloon.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: This happened yesterday in Kowloon. Workers at a casino in Macau striking over conditions-- three have died in one bunk house. CIA thinks there may be a connection. Cheever writes down the numbers.

dialogues.speaker: HAGGERTY
dialogues.text: Casinos are of particular concern to Homeland Security.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: If someone is ready to blow themselves up at a pizzeria, then the thought of walking through a crowded casino or an airport spreading Small Pox or anthrax must have crossed their mind. We're asking for a list of casino guests.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: What did they die of? The three.

dialogues.speaker: PRENCH
dialogues.text: Reports are vague~- seizures, comas. Cheever and Haggerty share a look.

dialogues.speaker: HAGGERTY
dialogues.text: We've’ reached out to WHO-- see what they know.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: Emhoff traveled to Hong Kong-- I’11l check on Macau. She stopped in Chicago on the way home.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: And? Beat. Cheever knows what's coming.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER -
dialogues.text: We know of at least one death in Chicago-- no confirmation yet. But, we believe that Emhoff was in contact with the Chicago case.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: We've run scenarios like this. We're going to want to alert the administration and the NSA. When will we know how to stop this?

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: After we figure out what it is—- and if it’s the same thing everywhere. French is not happy with this answer.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: Is there any way someone could weaponize bird flu? Is that what we’re looking at?

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: Someone doesn’t have to weaponize bird flu. That's what the birds are doing. INT. cDC - LAB - SIMULTANEOUSLY THE VIRUS! Electron microscopy shows irregular spheres wi spikes. There are bulbs at the end of spikes that fit int human cells like keys in locks.

dialogues.speaker: A MONITOR
dialogues.text: The Virus has been isolated. Eisenberg and Hextall puzzle over it.

dialogues.speaker: HEXTALL
dialogues.text: Go in a field. Eisenberg clicks a mouse and the virus enlarges.

dialogues.speaker: EISENBERG
dialogues.text: I'm not seeing much cross- reactivity. Her body had no idea what to do about it.

dialogues.speaker: HEXTALL
dialogues.text: Novel. Shit. Another computer display spells it out in genetic. sequen A series of consonants and numbers spell out a brand new word. HEXTALL (CONT‘D) Send the image to Sussman in San Francisco and Feldman in New York. See if they have any ideas. But, I don’t want it going wide yet.

dialogues.speaker: ETSENBERG
dialogues.text: What do we say upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: HEXTALL
dialogues.text: All we can tell them is what it’s not-- and they can tell the world what that means. INT. ORANTES’ OFFICE - NIGHT She watches the Marunouchi Line video again and again. Th have now been two million hits. It has gone viral. She notices something. Pauses the video. She makes it ful screen.

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN
dialogues.text: The man carries a BAG on his shoulder-- when he tumbles, the contents spill out. THE DUBIOUS COLLEAGUE from the earlier briefing works acr the hall. She yells to him.

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something? He walks into hex office.

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What does that look like to you?

dialogues.speaker: DUBIOUS
dialogues.text: Airplane ticket.

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: Which airline?

dialogues.speaker: DUBIOUS
dialogues.text: I’m not. sure, I don’t fly that much. - —_ Orantes types quickly on her computer-- brings up the AIR CHINA HOMEPAGE. The colors on’ the website match the tick jacket lying near the Marunounchi Man.

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: This one?

dialogues.speaker: DUBIOUS
dialogues.text: Looks like it to me.

dialogues.speaker: ORANTES
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The futures floor is crowded with TRADERS shoulder to shoulder waiting for the day to begin. A MAN WITH A ROUGH VOICE gets up with a microphone.

dialogues.speaker: ROUGH VOICE
dialogues.text: Over the weekend, a friend and colleague passed away. Joshua Neal. He was a good father. A good man. Anda loyal friend. I'd like us all to join in a moment of silence for our co-worker Josh Neal. Silence spreads across the men in the pits. They search t top of their shoes for solace. The silence is punctuated with the HOARSE COUGH of a TRADER BREAKING A SWEAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mears, Swanson and other MEMBERS of an INVESTIGATIVE TEAM enter the office building on a mission. They wear DEPT OF HEALTH windbreakers-- some wear masks, all wear gloves. T carry vessels for containment of biological matter. A HUMAN RESOURCES WORKER points toward the stairs. It fee like an FBI raid.

dialogues.speaker: HR WORKER
dialogues.text: Ms. Emhoff was on the third floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swanson and the team head into the stairwell. Mears leads the way with the HR worker.

dialogues.speaker: HR WORKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have the list you asked. for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands her a slip of paper.

dialogues.speaker: HR WORKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're in the conference room on the fifth floor. They were told to keep ten feet apart.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: By whom?

dialogues.speaker: HR WORKER
dialogues.text: The on-site nurse, There was a lot of anxiety and it seemed getting them all in the same place and away from the other employees would be best. We closed up the bathroom she was using and brought in a cleaning team.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLEANING TEAM
dialogues.text: Ten strong and fully outfitted. Washing down every work surface and keyboard with ammonia and Lysol and anything that kills the small and nasty. They treat it like it’s a hazardous waste spill.

dialogues.speaker: SWANSON
dialogues.text: We’re not gonna get much here-~ pretty much been sanitized.

dialogues.speaker: INT, FIFTH FLOOR CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: Mears addresses a group of ELEVEN NERVOUS EMPLOYEES.

dialogues.speaker: NERVOUS 1
dialogues.text: There was a package she messengered from Hong Kong that I opened.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Shouldn't be an issue-- virus can’t live for days on a box. Anybody meet her at the airport or see her when she got back? Nervous looks all around.

dialogues.speaker: NERVOUS 2
dialogues.text: Sometimes we do pilates together, but she didn’t feel up to it.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: So, you had no contact with her?

dialogues.speaker: NERVOUS 2
dialogues.text: Only over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: NERVOUS 3
dialogues.text: (holds. forward a coffee cup) We had coffee the day she came in-- I think she might have moved my. cup because it was on some papers. I can’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: SWANSON
dialogues.text: How many days ago?

dialogues.speaker: NERVOUS 3
dialogues.text: Six. I’d like to be tested-- my head is buzzing. People move away from her.

dialogues.speaker: HR WORKER 1
dialogues.text: The security log says that Dave Amdahl was here during those hours.

dialogues.speaker: NERVOUS 1
dialogues.text: Dave worked on another floor.

dialogues.speaker: SWANSON
dialogues.text: Was he at the meeting?

dialogues.speaker: NERVOUS 3
dialogues.text: No, but he was: with her.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: And how’s that?

dialogues.speaker: NERVOUS 3
dialogues.text: Her car was stuck in the snow and he pushed it out.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Where is he? HR calls down to his office. Everyone waits and watches.

dialogues.speaker: HR WORKER
dialogues.text: May I speak to Dave...Uh...uh...20 minutes. She hangs up. HR WORKER (CONT ’D} He got a late start this morning-~ he’s on his way in.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Does you have his cell. phone number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVE AMDAHL (30‘s) on a crowded city bus-- he coughs and drinks his coffee. Looks a little sweaty-- not great. His phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: AMDAHL
dialogues.text: Hello...This is. Yeah, should be there soon...I got a late. start today. Two sick ones at home. Needed to get my sister to-‘come over and stay with them...... A long pause as we hear Mears trying to remain calm on th other. end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where are you at this moment?

dialogues.speaker: AMDAHL
dialogues.text: On the bus. He pulls the wire to signal the bus to stop at the next corner. Anxiety building. AMDAHL (CONT’D) Yeah, I‘m getting off. He does. EXT. MINNEAPOLIS STREET CORNER — CONTINUOUS People mill about. Amdahl is still on the phone. Freaked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTAGION 1/14/10 Sl.

dialogues.speaker: AMDAHL
dialogues.text: She couldn‘t get the car out so I helped. I pushed for a while, but then I just drove it out for her... He looks at his own hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMDAHL (CONT’D) They were on the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mears drives to get Amdahl-- sirens blazing. Speaks. to : Cheever who is on the phone in his office. ‘

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: As of this morning we have somewhere between 22 and 39 fatalities-- but people are coming back from the holiday-- could get crazy. .Two more deaths last night. Both connected to the hospital-- ER nurse who saw Emhoff and another patient in the ER.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: Hextall says it’s novel. Sussman says it's mosaic. Feldman says it’s part human and part pig-- but not H1IN1. We‘re trying to put together a press statement for this afternoon. We've got dead in Tokyo, London, Macau and the WHO is telling us the Chinese quarantined an apartment building-- they have

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: five dead.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Out of how many?

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: They’re not saying.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: You gonna call a national emergency?

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: And say what? We can’t hide from the air. Can’t spell pandemic without spelling panic. Still cold there?  CONTAGION 1/14/10 52.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: Until July from what I understand. Just bought a down parka and wool hat. I‘li be expensing those. There‘s a football game here tonight. Sixty thousand people in a small space, using the same~rést rooms and water fountains.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: We called the governor-~ he has tickets on the 50 yard line.

dialogues.speaker: MEARS
dialogues.text: I gotta go-- we found our spreader. They arrive at Amdahl. He sinks to his knees-- terrified. MEARS (CONT‘D) Mr. Amdahl, I want you to put on this mask and get in the ambulance. We believe you may have come in contact with a highly contagious virus. OK? Do you understand? He is given a mask and climbs into the ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a conference room with an American Flag framed on the wali, three U.S. OFFICIALS IN SUITS sit with Rafik and a LAWYER. Two of the officials wear N-95 masks and the thir PACES.

dialogues.speaker: PACES
dialogues.text: Prior to London you were in Hong Kong and Macau. Prior to that you were in Dubai and Riyadh.

dialogues.speaker: RAFIK'S LAWYER
dialogues.text: We have provided a complete itinerary.

dialogues.speaker: RAFIK
dialogues.text: Are the masks necessary? No one here is ill. They ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL 1
dialogues.text: And the young woman who died in London? You had known her long?

dialogues.speaker: RAFIK
dialogues.text: We met last spring in Chamonix. RAFIK’S LAWYER He has meetings in Miami next week. I don’t understand--

dialogues.speaker: RAFIK
dialogues.text: I’ve never had a visa request rejected before. I've had two congressmen as guests here in Dubai.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL 2
dialogues.text: Also, we understand your butler died of an undetermined illness as well this week.

dialogues.speaker: PACES
dialogues.text: Is gambling a passion of yours, Mr. Khalifa? Have you been to Las Vegas? Atlantic City? Macau?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. RAFIK’S LAWYER You know he was in Macau.

dialogues.speaker: PACES
dialogues.text: You have holdings in two Romanian drug companies. We'd like to talk to you more about that, Mr. Khalifa.

dialogues.speaker: RAFIRK
dialogues.text: This is bullshit. Absurd.

dialogues.speaker: RAFIK'S LAWYER
dialogues.text: He's lost a loved one and an employee in the last week or so-~ he himself has been ill. Why are you harassing him?

dialogues.speaker: PACES
dialogues.text: There are people in this part of the world who have stated an interest in biological weapons. Do you know any of these people? Rafik gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL 1
dialogues.text: We would like a blood sample, Mr. Khalifa.  CONTAGION 1/14/10 54.

dialogues.speaker: RAFIK
dialogues.text: What are you saying? I killed someone?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL 1
dialogues.text: We'd like a blood test to be administered by a physician-- affiliated with the US military here-~ I think you can understand how we would arrive at such a request. We mean no offense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slides an appointment card toward him.

dialogues.speaker: RAFIK
dialogues.text: I‘d Like to go now. I’11 be contacting Senator Schumer's office about this. He leaves the card on the table.

dialogues.speaker: HAGGERTY., (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (prelap) It’s always a good idea to have water and canned goods on hand... INT. CDC —- PRESS CONFERENCE - DAY Cheever holds forth before a sea of reporters. Haggerty a a group of other grim faced officials stand behind him. T are active on their Blackberries-- new reports are walked

dialogues.speaker: RAGGERTY
dialogues.text: -.- Regardless if the threat is an earthquake or outbreak or hurricane. All emergency service providers advocate that. I’m going to turn it over te Dr. zllis Cheever, Deputy Director of our Infectious Disease Center.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: OK. There is a release posted on our website that is updated hourly. Here's the situation in Minnesota-~ which is very fluid right now. 35 are believed dead. We are processing samples. Until we do that we can’t confirm that the deaths are the result of the same illness.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: Can you say what drugs you believe will be effective at this point? Antibiotics? Anitvirals?

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: I can’t. answer that. We need to identify the infectious agent first.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: Tamiflu? Relenza? Were they depleted by the Swine Flu outbreak?

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: It would be irresponsible to recommend a. course of treatment without an understanding of the disease.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: So, there’s no medical treatment?

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: We have isolated the virus, but not identified it. That’s job one.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: And when will it be identified? There are reports on the web out of Hong Kong that it’s avian flu. Can you comment on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the departures lounge, Orantes watches the press conference on CNN INTERNATIONAL.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: We do not believe this is H5N1-- or a mutated HIN1. The World Health Organization has sent an epidemiologist to Hong Kong to try and identify the origins of whatever it is we are looking at. We do know that the person in Minnesota who appears to be the index patient had travelled to that part of the world.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: But, you don’t know what it is?  CONTAGION 1/14/10 56.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: That doesn’t stop us from knowing what it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 3
dialogues.text: Are you issuing any warning about plane travel at this point?--Or, schools?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. NICE BOUSE — EDINA, MINNESOTA - SIMULTANEOUSLY Emhoff watches the conference on a local NBC affiliate wi Jory.

dialogues.speaker: HAGGERTY
dialogues.text: The cpc is in discussions with Homeland Security and other branches of government and we refer you to our website for updates on warnings and school closures. That will be up to the states.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 4
dialogues.text: Is the FDA prepared to pull any foods or issue any warnings? Farmers in Iowa have voluntarily culled birds today and farmers in Texas are following suit. |

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: There is no reason to believe at this point that food stocks have been compromised. |

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 4
dialogues.text: But, you don’t know? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: We believe it is passed by normal respiration from an infected person. We have posted symptoms on the website-- One more question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krumwiede watches on FOX NEWS.  CONTAGION 1/14/10 57.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 5
dialogues.text: There is blogging on the internet from credible sources that this may be a biological weapon we are seeing. In fact, an extremist organization has taken credit on the internet-- an Algerian..gzoup with ties to Saudi Arabia...

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: Again, that’s not my world. We are in touch with Homeland Security--

dialogues.speaker: HAGGERTY
dialogues.text: And we are sharing information and samples with health and intelligence organizations around the world. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 3
dialogues.text: Can you repeat the affected cities \ so far? ,

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: Again, the US cities affected are Minneapolis, Chicago, Los Angeles, Boston and Salt Lake...We expect that number to grow as people return from their holidays. Cheever steps away from the podium.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Your name again.

dialogues.speaker: CHEEVER
dialogues.text: Ellis Cheever...C-H-E-E-V-E-R. INT. METRODOME —- MINNESOTA The Vikings are playing the GIANTS-- MONDAY NIGHT FOOTBAL There are some empty seats. A few fans wear N~95 protecti masks, most do not. There is a crawl on the scoreboard th says: "The Minneapolis Health Department reminds you to cover your mouth when you cough and wash your hands frequently.” A SOFT PRETZEL makes its way down a row of FANS and a TWE DOLLAR BILL makes its way back toward the vendor who lick his fingers and peels off change. A conveyor belt of viru spread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mears watches the game on TV. She has some soup and salad At the bar THREE DELTA FLIGHT ATTENDANTS talk among themselves.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: The company is saying that if we think someone is sick we need to repert them. Are we gonna throw them out at 30,000 feet? ATTENDANT 2 ; Has the union said anything yet? I hear that BA is stopping flights te Chicago and Boston.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: There’s a thing today on the internet that there are samples | missing from the Army labs in j Maryland. That's what this is. : They were trying to make a flu shot i and this happened. Someone messed | up big time. i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mears signs her check. |
